content.description: Awesome, low percentage slabbing! Starts as for Mr. Bo Trundle (10d) but shoots straight for the beautiful, left-angling seam. The mid section is stout and ends at a decent rest before the "slab", seam section above. High crux (for me) at about bolt 6. The chains seem pretty far away after clipping bolt 7, but it is cruiser.
content.protection:
7 bolts.  Can cool temps, sticky rubber & vice grips be part of the required protection?  Shares chain anchor with

Sunshine Daydream

.
content.location:
Left-angling seam up (approx center) beautiful, golden, Thindependence Wall (upper tier).

You will be able to pick it out!

content.description: Trend right at the start to establish under the finger crack proper. Get good gear (small TCU) from stance and gun up a tricky sequence to find more small gear and tricky and polished climbing above! The face is really polished so you may find it pumpy for the grade. Move left under roof section and continue up overhanging blocky dihedral to chains.
content.protection: Standard rack. A couple extra small cams and wires.  Chain anchor.
content.location: This is the obvious, finger crack up the center of the lower tier of the Thindependence Wall.

content.description: A harder & steeper start gives way to more great (and a bit easier) climbing above.
content.location:
It is atop some blocks and left of an obvious and beautiful, left-trending seam that is

Gold Finger

(12a). The climbing starts in/around right-facing dihedral and runs up to join anchors with

Gold Finger

.

content.description: Begin with easy climbing for several bolts.  At mid-height, you are at the obvious slabby, smeary crux.  On the left side of the bolts at the crux, the route climbs at ~11a.  On the right side it feels a bit harder with slapping for slopers (hence the name) and is probably the reason it is rated 11c in the guide.  Its just a sport climb, so either way works.  Short but sweet.
content.location: The easiest way to approach Slap Happy is to hike up to Junior Olympic Wall, make a hard right just before it and step up onto a small bench, which is the farthest left side of Thindependence Wall.  You can belay here (recommended) or move up and left of the route near the first bolt.  You can see the route from the trail when you are below it.

climbs.name: Satanic Mechanic
climbs.fa: T. Perkins, M. Lake, B. D'Antonio

content.description: Climb the thin face to a good horizontal break with a piton (might want to clip with a long sling).  From here, climb through roofs on jugs and some tricky moves to the anchors that are located on the underside of the huge roof at clifftop.
content.location:
This route is located a little ways back from the main trail that climbs along the Outrageous Overhangs cliffs.  Pass

Walk in Central Park

, then look for a small trail that leads uphill to the right into a small alcove.

content.description: This route doesn't look like much from the ground, but the upper half is surprisingly fun with good movement.  It is a nice warm-up and is worth doing.
content.protection:
6 bolts to chains.

Per

Jay 1975

: this can be led on gear.
content.location:
This is to the right of

Thindependence

crack.

climbs.name: Ratchet
climbs.fa: T. Perkins, N. Beidleman, S. Malkin, 2004

content.description: Start through some ledgy sections, but move up to some exciting crimps through good, steep rock. The bolts are good through the crux, but there is a large runout that can be protected with gear down low.
content.protection: 6 bolts to chains. A small cam is optional between the 2nd and 3rd bolts.
content.location:
This route is to the right of

Spookalator

.

climbs.name: Rat Salad
climbs.fa: J. Fassett, T. Perkins, B. D'Antonio, 1992

content.description:
Aptly named: edible, perhaps even satiating, but lacking top-shelf ingredients, this route offers some fun, airy moves that will get you pumped, but the rock is a wee bit sharp with scaly holds that are prone to crumbling. I doubt this line will ever clean up. Stickclip the first bolt, and have your belayer wear a helmet.

Adding to the appeal, however, is that it stays pretty shady in this alcove.
content.protection: 5 or 6 quickdraws plus two more for the anchor and a stickclip.
content.location:
The first high bolt is located on the left side of the huge overhang that houses

Satanic Mechanic

.

content.description: Follow two dihedrals up into a roof and finishing on the slab above.  The crux is pulling the roof.
content.location:
This is located directly to the right of bolted crack climb that arches to the left (

Gold Finger

, 12c).

climbs.name: Me First
climbs.fa: N. Beidleman, T. Perkins, S. Malkin, 2004

content.description:
This weird route is more like a V2+ boulder problem with some forgettable 5.10 approach climbing and a gear-protected finish on easy slab. I enjoyed this route more for the novel puzzle than for the actual movement. Fortunately there is a small ledge that allows a person to down climb and recover while reconnoitering the crux before committing to the blind moves.

Once over the lip, a long 5.7 slab leads to the chains above—it's not a bad idea to bring 1.5" and 2" cams to protect the finish.
content.protection: A couple of finger- to hand-size cams, 9 quickdraws, and a 60-meter rope.
content.location:
This route starts in the black, jumbled rock about 15 feet left of

Magic Fingers

and weaves up between the triangular corners and roofs at the top.

content.description: Start on a short, slabby section, and clip a lone bolt to get to the magic fingers corner in the finger crack. The crux is pulling over a bulge section with some thin feet and smearing.
content.protection: A standard rack with an emphasis on finger sizes.
content.location:
It is immediately left of

Thindependence

in an obvious corner with a finger crack.

content.description:
This starts in a dihedral and begins by following a large crack up and to the left before heading straight up.

The large, left-angling crack and a horizontal break in the rock about halfway up distinguishes this climb.
content.location: This is most easily accessed by heading to the Junior Olympic Wall but turning right and traversing onto a ledge right before you get to the area. It can also be accessed by taking the normal route to Thindependence, then following the cliff climber's left until you reach a ledge with a tree on it above the trail toward Junior Olympic Wall.
